nodes.description: A state of mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or very demanding circumstances.
A feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease, typically about an imminent event or something with an uncertain outcome.
A state of emotional, physical, and mental exhaustion caused by excessive and prolonged stress.
A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.
Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) is an eight-week evidence-based program that offers secular, intensive mindfulness training to assist people with stress, anxiety, depression and pain.
Habits and practices that are conducive to sleeping well on a regular basis.
The amount of time spent using a device with a screen such as a smartphone, computer, television, or video game console.

documents.title: Understanding Burnout
documents.content: Burnout is a reaction to prolonged or chronic job stress and is characterized by three main dimensions: exhaustion, cynicism (less identification with the job), and feelings of reduced professional ability. Healthcare workers are particularly susceptible post-COVID.

documents.title: Impact of Screen Time on Sleep
documents.content: Blue light emitted by screens restricts the production of melatonin, the hormone that controls your sleep-wake cycle (circadian rhythm). Reducing screen time at least an hour before bedtime can significantly improve sleep quality.

documents.title: MBSR for Healthcare Workers
documents.content: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) has been shown to significantly reduce perceived stress and burnout symptoms in healthcare professionals. The program involves meditation, body scanning, and yoga.

documents.title: Social Media and Depression
documents.content: Studies indicate a strong correlation between heavy social media usage and depression rates in young adults. The 'compare and despair' factor plays a significant role in lowering self-esteem and increasing depressive symptoms.

documents.title: Coping with Anxiety
documents.content: Anxiety can be managed through various techniques including cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), mindfulness, regular exercise, and maintaining a healthy sleep schedule. Avoiding caffeine and alcohol can also help reduce symptoms.
